title: Karma Sannyasa Yoga
subtitle: The Yoga of Renunciation of Action
summary: In Chapter 5, Krishna reconciles the paths of selfless action (Karma Yoga) and renunciation (Sannyasa). He explains that true renunciation means performing duties without attachment to results, not merely abandoning action. The perfected yogi sees inaction in action and action in inaction, attaining peace through surrender to the Divine.

verses.sanskrit: अर्जुन उवाच | संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि | यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम् ||
verses.transliteration: arjuna uvāca | sannyāsaṃ karmaṇāṃ kṛṣṇa punar yogaṃ ca śaṃsasi | yac chreya etayor ekaṃ tan me brūhi su-niścitam ||
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O Krishna, You praise renunciation (Sannyasa) and also performance of action (Yoga). Tell me decisively which one is better.
verses.explanation: Arjuna seeks clarity between two seemingly contradictory paths: renunciation of action vs. engaged action.

verses.sanskrit: श्रीभगवानुवाच | संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ | तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते ||
verses.transliteration: śrī bhagavān uvāca | sannyāsaḥ karma-yogaś ca niḥśreyasa-karāv ubhau | tayos tu karma-sannyāsāt karma-yogo viśiṣyate ||
verses.translation: The Blessed Lord said: Both renunciation and Karma Yoga lead to liberation. But of the two, Karma Yoga is superior to mere renunciation of action.
verses.explanation: Krishna states that while both paths are valid, selfless action (Karma Yoga) is more practical for most seekers.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति | निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते ||
verses.transliteration: jñeyaḥ sa nitya-sannyāsī yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati | nirdvandvo hi mahā-bāho sukhaṃ bandhāt pramucyate ||
verses.translation: One who neither hates nor desires should be known as a perpetual renunciant. O mighty-armed, free from dualities, one is easily liberated from bondage.
verses.explanation: True renunciation is an inner state of equanimity, not external abandonment.

verses.sanskrit: साङ्ख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः | एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् ||
verses.transliteration: sāṅkhya-yogau pṛthag bālāḥ pravadanti na paṇḍitāḥ | ekam apy āsthitaḥ samyag ubhayor vindate phalam ||
verses.translation: Only the ignorant speak of Sankhya (knowledge) and Yoga (action) as different. The wise know that whoever is firmly established in one attains the fruits of both.
verses.explanation: The paths of knowledge and action converge for those who practice either with sincerity.

verses.sanskrit: यत्साङ्ख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते | एकं साङ्ख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति ||
verses.transliteration: yat sāṅkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṃ tad yogair api gamyate | ekaṃ sāṅkhyaṃ ca yogaṃ ca yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati ||
verses.translation: The state attained by the Sankhyites (through knowledge) is also reached by the Yogis (through action). One who sees Sankhya and Yoga as one truly sees.
verses.explanation: The destination (Self-realization) is identical for both paths.

verses.sanskrit: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः | योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति ||
verses.transliteration: sannyāsas tu mahā-bāho duḥkham āptum ayogataḥ | yoga-yukto munir brahma na cireṇādhigacchati ||
verses.translation: O mighty-armed, mere renunciation without Karma Yoga is painful to attain. But the sage united with Yoga quickly attains Brahman.
verses.explanation: Forced physical renunciation without inner discipline leads to suffering.

verses.sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः | सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते ||
verses.transliteration: yoga-yukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ | sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtātmā kurvann api na lipyate ||
verses.translation: One who is united with Yoga, pure in heart, self-controlled, and victorious over the senses—though acting, such a person remains unattached.
verses.explanation: The perfected yogi acts without ego, seeing the Self in all beings.

verses.sanskrit: नैव किञ्चित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित् | पश्यञ्शृण्वन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपञ्श्वसन् ||
verses.transliteration: naiva kiñcit karomīti yukto manyeta tattva-vit | paśyañ śṛṇvan spṛśañ jighrann aśnan gacchan svapañ śvasan ||
verses.translation: The knower of truth, united with Yoga, thinks, 'I do nothing at all,' even while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving, sleeping, or breathing.
verses.explanation: The enlightened perceive actions as natural functions of the body, not the Self.

verses.sanskrit: प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि | इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् ||
verses.transliteration: pralapan visṛjan gṛhṇann unmiṣan nimiṣann api | indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣu vartanta iti dhārayan ||
verses.translation: Speaking, releasing, grasping, opening, and closing the eyes—one who understands that the senses operate among sense objects remains unattached.
verses.explanation: Detachment comes from witnessing the senses' interactions without identification.

verses.sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः | लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा ||
verses.transliteration: brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padma-patram ivāmbhasā ||
verses.translation: One who performs actions without attachment, offering them to Brahman, is untouched by sin—like a lotus leaf by water.
verses.explanation: Surrendered action leaves no karmic residue.

verses.sanskrit: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि | योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वात्मशुद्धये ||
verses.transliteration: kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalair indriyair api | yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṃ tyaktvātma-śuddhaye ||
verses.translation: The yogis perform actions only with the body, mind, intellect, or senses, abandoning attachment, for self-purification.
verses.explanation: Actions become tools for purification when performed without ego.

verses.sanskrit: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम् | अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते ||
verses.transliteration: yuktaḥ karma-phalaṃ tyaktvā śāntim āpnoti naiṣṭhikīm | ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate ||
verses.translation: The united one, abandoning the fruits of action, attains eternal peace. The disunited one, attached to results, becomes bound.
verses.explanation: Detachment from outcomes leads to liberation; attachment breeds bondage.

verses.sanskrit: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी | नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् ||
verses.transliteration: sarva-karmāṇi manasā sannyasyāste sukhaṃ vaśī | nava-dvāre pure dehī naiva kurvan na kārayan ||
verses.translation: The embodied one who mentally renounces all actions dwells happily in the nine-gated city (the body), neither acting nor causing action.
verses.explanation: The Self, though residing in the body, is ever-free from actions.

verses.sanskrit: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः | न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते ||
verses.transliteration: na kartṛtvaṃ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ | na karma-phala-saṃyogaṃ svabhāvas tu pravartate ||
verses.translation: The Lord does not create agency, actions, or the fruits of actions for the world. Nature (Prakriti) alone operates.
verses.explanation: God is the witness; the interplay of gunas drives all activity.

verses.sanskrit: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः | अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः ||
verses.transliteration: nādatte kasyacit pāpaṃ na caiva sukṛtaṃ vibhuḥ | ajñānenāvṛtaṃ jñānaṃ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ ||
verses.translation: The Supreme Lord does not take responsibility for anyone's sin or virtue. Wisdom is obscured by ignorance, and thereby beings are deluded.
verses.explanation: Delusion arises from ignorance, not divine will.

verses.sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः | तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् ||
verses.transliteration: jñānena tu tad ajñānaṃ yeṣāṃ nāśitam ātmanaḥ | teṣām āditya-vaj jñānaṃ prakāśayati tat param ||
verses.translation: But for those whose ignorance is destroyed by Self-knowledge, that wisdom shines like the sun, revealing the Supreme.
verses.explanation: Self-knowledge dispels ignorance just as sunlight banishes darkness.

verses.sanskrit: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः | गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः ||
verses.transliteration: tad-buddhayas tad-ātmānas tan-niṣṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ | gacchanty apunar-āvṛttiṃ jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣāḥ ||
verses.translation: Those whose intellect is fixed in That, whose Self is merged in That, steadfast in That, and devoted to That—their sins dispelled by wisdom, they attain liberation.
verses.explanation: Total absorption in the Divine leads to freedom from rebirth.

verses.sanskrit: विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि | शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः ||
verses.transliteration: vidyā-vinaya-sampanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini | śuni caiva śva-pāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ ||
verses.translation: The wise see with equanimity a learned Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even an outcaste.
verses.explanation: Enlightened beings perceive the same Atman in all forms.

verses.sanskrit: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः | निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः ||
verses.transliteration: ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣāṃ sāmye sthitaṃ manaḥ | nirdoṣaṃ hi samaṃ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ ||
verses.translation: Here in this world, they have conquered rebirth, whose minds rest in equality. Flawless is Brahman, and equal—thus they abide in Brahman.
verses.explanation: Equanimity is the mark of one established in Brahman.

verses.sanskrit: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम् | स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः ||
verses.transliteration: na prahṛṣyet priyaṃ prāpya nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam | sthira-buddhir asammūḍho brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ ||
verses.translation: One who neither rejoices in the pleasant nor grieves at the unpleasant, with steady intellect and undeluded—such a knower of Brahman is established in Brahman.
verses.explanation: The realized being remains unshaken by dualities.

verses.sanskrit: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम् | स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते ||
verses.transliteration: bāhya-sparśeṣv asaktātmā vindaty ātmani yat sukham | sa brahma-yoga-yuktātmā sukham akṣayam aśnute ||
verses.translation: With the Self unattached to external contacts, one finds happiness within. United with Brahman through Yoga, one enjoys imperishable bliss.
verses.explanation: Inner joy is independent of sensory experiences.

verses.sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते | आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः ||
verses.transliteration: ye hi saṃsparśa-jā bhogā duḥkha-yonaya eva te | ādy-antavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ ||
verses.translation: O son of Kunti, pleasures born of contact are wombs of pain, for they have a beginning and an end. The wise do not delight in them.
verses.explanation: Worldly pleasures are transient and ultimately painful.

verses.sanskrit: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात् | कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः ||
verses.transliteration: śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṃ prāk śarīra-vimokṣaṇāt | kāma-krodhodbhavaṃ vegaṃ sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ ||
verses.translation: One who can withstand the urges of lust and anger before death is a yogi and a happy person.
verses.explanation: Mastery over impulses is the sign of a true yogi.

verses.sanskrit: योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः | स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति ||
verses.transliteration: yo 'ntaḥ-sukho 'ntarārāmas tathāntar-jyotir eva yaḥ | sa yogī brahma-nirvāṇaṃ brahma-bhūto 'dhigacchati ||
verses.translation: One whose happiness is within, whose joy is within, and whose light is within—that yogi attains liberation in Brahman, becoming Brahman.
verses.explanation: The Self-realized find fulfillment in the Atman alone.

verses.sanskrit: लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः | छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः ||
verses.transliteration: labhante brahma-nirvāṇam ṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇa-kalmaṣāḥ | chinna-dvaidhā yatātmānaḥ sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ ||
verses.translation: The sages attain liberation in Brahman—their sins destroyed, doubts dispelled, senses mastered, and engaged in the welfare of all beings.
verses.explanation: Liberated beings naturally serve others selflessly.

verses.sanskrit: कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम् | अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम् ||
verses.transliteration: kāma-krodha-viyuktānāṃ yatīnāṃ yata-cetasām | abhito brahma-nirvāṇaṃ vartate viditātmanām ||
verses.translation: For those free from desire and anger, self-controlled and knowing the Self, liberation in Brahman exists everywhere.
verses.explanation: The liberated perceive Brahman in all directions.

verses.sanskrit: स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः | प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ ||
verses.transliteration: sparśān kṛtvā bahir bāhyāṃś cakṣuś caivāntare bhruvoḥ | prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā nāsābhyantara-cāriṇau ||
verses.translation: Shutting out external objects, fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, equalizing the inward and outward breaths moving within the nostrils—
verses.explanation: A technique for meditation: withdrawing the senses and regulating prana.

verses.sanskrit: यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः | विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः ||
verses.transliteration: yatendriya-mano-buddhir munir mokṣa-parāyaṇaḥ | vigatecchā-bhaya-krodho yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ ||
verses.translation: The sage who controls the senses, mind, and intellect, intent on liberation, free from desire, fear, and anger—is ever liberated.
verses.explanation: Mastery over the inner instruments leads to perpetual freedom.

verses.sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम् | सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति ||
verses.transliteration: bhoktāraṃ yajña-tapasāṃ sarva-loka-maheśvaram | suhṛdaṃ sarva-bhūtānāṃ jñātvā māṃ śāntim ṛcchati ||
verses.translation: Knowing Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the Supreme Lord of all worlds, and the friend of all beings, one attains peace.
verses.explanation: Recognizing Krishna as the ultimate beneficiary and well-wisher brings serenity.
